comments.commentBody: I am eagerly awaiting the Gulf of Mexico Wall and the Great Upper Vs. Baja California Wall.  The former will be strong enough to stop hurricanes.
This if true can be addressed.

Age 25 is potentially too old to make this choice. Age 0.01 is potentially too old to make this choice (assuming parents could make binding decisions for their off-spring). By age 25, you already know a great deal about your personal risk, based on genetic factors and your lifestyle choices up to that point. There would, of course, still be quite a lot of risk that couldn't be predicted at that age, but many people would definitely know whether they were at elevated risk or particularly low risk.

It's an empirical question to what extent people would use that knowledge to risk-sort. If there were a lot of risk sorting, the system would drive large price differentials between the two paths you've laid out, increasing the pressure for still more risk sorting.

And all of this begs the question of what to do about the young. Are people under the age of 25 covered under their parents' pathways? (Which parent?) Or is there another mechanism entirely for them? Which system covers pre-natal care? What do we do with immigrants over the age of 25? What do we do with people in emergencies whose identities cannot be verified?

Grr. This belongs on the first post, of course.

Hey John, have a great time with the family and if you need a guest blogger for your avatar, let me know.
Well nothing is 100% effective but your examples did stop many from trying and some who did not succeed.
Excellent points, lets include this in the bill.
The only thing that the Mets have to do to get lucky is to play the Phillies every night. I am VERY disgusted.

Harvey and Wheeler and young gems--perhaps they'll go on to win Cy Young Awards and then be traded, or become free agents and depart as the Mets' star hurlers did in the late '70s. They certainly won't be leading a Mets team to the Series--ownership will see to it.

It's hard to be a Mets fan these days!
I think I missed the part of the article that explains what's positive about the Mets.
How can you forget winning in '86 and losing to the Yankees in 2000? For all the suffering that we Met fans have endured, how many times have The Cubs,Padres Astros etc been to the World Series?
Love the corn on the cob from Tacos de Verano!

@Fed Up: The Mets' AA team is in Binghamton (the B-Mets) of the Eastern League. The Rochester Red Wings are a long time AAA team in the International League, and a Twins affiliate.

As a dear friend from Brazil told me way back in the 80s (about the time Keith Hernandez arrived, in tears, from St. Louis) "Brazil is the future and it always will be." Ask Yogi if the "Mets' future is still ahead of them?"

Last year, despite an average that hovered at about .220, Ike Davis hit 32 home runs to lead the team (by far). On tonight's broadcast, Ronnie gave Gary a five point hitting checklist Davis is going through in Las Vegas. He is totally lost, and, in the memorable advice of Crash Davis to Nuke LaLoosh: "Don't think, Meat, you can only hurt the ball club."

And before Jay exults about the young, home grown pitching staff, Jon Niese left that game with a bum throwing shoulder tonight. Hey, our Metsies were the first team to win a series in Atlanta from the Braves since last August, and they swept the Yankees four games. So how do they have a 3-8 record against the even more woeful Miami Marlins? The unvarnished truth is that only Houston and Miami have worse records than do the Mets. Better days ahead? Do we have some major league level outfielders now?
Buck had 10 home runs in April. The Mets got all of five home runs from last year's catchers ALL SEASON. Buck had one HR in May and now one in June. Yikes!

@jstern: Sainted Joan's daughter was named Lorinda De Roulet, and it was a relief when she sold the team to Nelson Doubleday and Fred Wilpon. The die was cast for this franchise when Wilpon somehow maneuvered to force majority owner Doubleday (a descendant of Abner Doubleday, purportedly the inventor of the game) to sell to Wilpon against his will. Think it was a curse for the Red Sox to sell Babe Ruth to fund a Broadway play? How about forcing out a descendant of a Civil War hero-general who might have invented the game? Bernie Madoff was just icing on the cake. If you eliminate the non contributors being paid by the Mets this season, Johan Santana, Jason Bay and Frank Francisco, the payroll is among the lowest in MLB. If the finances are so parlous as to necessitate that level of penny pinching, then the owners simply *must* sell. They play in a beautiful, expensively built palace built with at least the backing of NY taxpayers in the form of tax-free municipal equivalent bonding ($800M worth). And the bottom line is (as is being revealed with the misbegotten garage at Yankee $tadium), in case of default, we taxpayers will prove to be on the hook, and that is in no way acceptable.
Why Jay feels we should be kind to the owners is a mystery to me. Even winning the series in Atlanta, the team is still 12 games under .500 and still has an inescapably inexcusable 3-8 record against the woeful Marlins. The opposite of love isn't hate, Jay; it's indifference. Ponder that, OK?

@shake re (B): Be fair, Murphy is an above average hitting second baseman who has made himself a pretty good fielder. Made three + plays tonight alone. BTW, Murphy is on pace for 50 doubles this season, 90 runs and 75 RBI.
Uh, D'Arnaud?

I believe it was in 2006 that Fred Wilpon stated that he wanted to model the Mets organize after the Atlanta Braves.  Given the Braves success this made sense.  With that said, Mr. Wilpon should follow Ted Turners lead and sell the Mets.

How about staying in their own country and working to feed their families?  Personally I would not do this so I guess i can be against reform.  I am for reform but not for more people coming to an already overpopulated country which has a bad unemployment problem.

Adding some more lemon juice to that paper cut:
-the hiring of Art "well, we battled" Howe
-the decision to move Mike Piazza to first base,and telling everybody about the move (except Mike Piazza)
-the classy way they fired Willie Randolph
-just 5 playoff appearances in 33 previous seasons of partial or full Wilpon ownership

As pleasant as the sweep was the other day, this team is almost certainly not going to win more than 65-68 games this year. That will be six consectutive years of declining victories. They have not one full-time MLB caliber outfielder, a bullpen that consists of Bobby Parnell and a bunch of prayers, one above average position player, one decent position player (Murphy), maybe a promising young catcher, though he's been hurt all year, so who knows. As others have said, as long as the Wilpons are around, there is truly little reason for long term hope. I've rooted for this team since the 60s and have seen bad eras before (see '77-'83, '91-'96, '01-'04) and know I will stick around, but it is disheartening.  Even Dolan will at least spend some money, if not particularly well.

I'm with RL.  Wheeler may or may not be the real thing.  Three words of caution before leaping to conclusions: Pulsipher.  Isringhauen.  Wilson.  And how long is Harvey's contract?  Who's to say he'll even stick around when the well-managed big money teams come calling.  It's one thing asking the fans to eat cake.  It's another when the cake isn't even half-baked!

I agree with Rhoden.  I love the game.  I'll spend my evenings coaching my kids' teams, I'll umpire games, I'll serve on the board of my local Little League.  But I will not shell out for a major league game until they stop treating me like an ignorant clown.  And -- although it seems very, very unlikely that I'll ever have to worry about it -- I'd be scared if my son ever made it to the minor leagues.  Why should a young man have to break the law and put his body at risk with drugs in order to follow his calling?  Baseball needs to get clean.

It costs too much to go and see this team. They are terrible, but the ticket prices don't reflect that. It's sad, but I just don't feel like I can take my family to the park anymore. If the team were more competitive, I could understand. But with the park half empty most of the time, it doesn't seem fair to charge so much.

I submitted a bunch of comments here, all of which have been dispatched to the ozone. Note to Jay: As Keith likes to say, you don't want to shoot the clown. Nice mention of the young, homegrown pitching staff just in time for Jonathon Niese to come up with a twinge in his pitching shoulder.
